reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Restoration of agriculture infrastructure and bakeries, with immediate food security assistance, in Deir ez Zor.

description.narrative:
Over 12 months, Oxfam will provide life-saving and life-sustaining support to 124,300 of the most vulnerable people in Ashara sub-district, Deir ez Zor. This will be achieved through three inter-linked work streams:
1. Food assistance through distribution of unconditional cash transfers to the most vulnerable households. Oxfam will provide two rounds of unconditional cash transfers (100,000 SYP per tranche) to 911 HHs, at least 30% of which will be headed by females. This will benefit a total of 6,377 individuals (based on average 7 family size) in acute need.
2. Rehabilitation of critical agriculture infrastructure through cash for work. This project is designed to combine provision of cash assistance with the restoration of essential productive infrastructure, by using the Cash for Work modality to rehabilitate agricultural irrigation channels. This will include rehabilitation and maintenance of irrigation equipment’s (irrigation pump, generators etc) through service providers and light rehabilitation work (cleaning and de-silting of irrigation canals through cash for work activities. Additional CfW activities will be developed for people who are not able or willing to carry out the physically demanding rehabilitation work, including pregnant and lactating women, people with disabilities and older people. Activities will be designed in conjunction with these stakeholders in the first few months of project implementation. This will provide immediate income generating activities to cash for work participants, and also by enabling farmers to restart their businesses. 50 households will be engaged in cash for work activity, each household will receive 20 days’ work (100,000 per each household – slightly better off households that are interested in labour) to meet their basic food needs.
This will benefit a total of 28,700 people.
3. Restoration of bakeries. Oxfam will repair and re-fit two bakeries, one in Sbeikhan and the other in Quiryeh. Oxfam will continue negotiations with relevant authorities (already underway) to ensure that the necessary flour, salt, yeast and fuel are allocated to each bakery.
This will benefit a total of 110,000 people.
Key stakeholders for this project, as well as community members and leaders themselves, will be relevant government ministries and agencies at national, governorate and local levels, and other humanitarian actors.
